MII-meso-tetrakis(2,3-dichlorophenyl)porphyrins as catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reaction under mild conditions: kinetic and theoretical investigation Jorge Luiz Sônego Milani a Werberson de Almeida Bezerra b Alexandre Moreira Meireles c Álvaro Farias Arruda da Mata b Frederico Henrique do Carmo Ferreira d Luiz Antônio Sodré Costa d Felipe Terra Martins b Dayse Carvalho da Silva Martins c Rafael Pavão das Chagas b ⁎ a Departamento de Química, Universidade Federal de Juiz de Fora, Juiz de Fora, MG, Brazil Departamento de Química Universidade Federal de Juiz de Fora Juiz de Fora MG Brazil aDepartamento de Química, Universidade Federal de Juiz de Fora, Juiz de Fora, MG, Brazil b Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal de Goiás – UFG, Goiânia, GO, Brazil Instituto de Química Universidade Federal de Goiás – UFG Goiânia GO Brazil bInstituto de Química, Universidade Federal de Goiás – UFG, Goiânia, GO, Brazil c Departamento de Química, Instituto de Ciências Exatas, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil Departamento de Química Instituto de Ciências Exatas Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais Belo Horizonte MG Brazil cDepartamento de Química, Instituto de Ciências Exatas, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil d NEQC – Núcleo de Estudos em Química Computacional, Departamento de Química, ICE, Universidade Federal de Juiz de Fora, Juiz de Fora, MG, Brazil NEQC – Núcleo de Estudos em Química Computacional Departamento de Química ICE Universidade Federal de Juiz de Fora Juiz de Fora MG Brazil dNEQC – Núcleo de Estudos em Química Computacional, Departamento de Química, ICE, Universidade Federal de Juiz de Fora, Juiz de Fora MG 36036-900, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. A series of new porphyrins with ZnII, CoII, and CuII (1-3) as metal centers are reported. These complexes were evaluated in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with epoxides under mild conditions (30-80°C and 1 bar of CO2 pressure) and solvent-free conditions; in optimal conditions, they presented high conversions (>99 %) and selectively produced styrene cyclic carbonate. To comprehend the mechanism of the reaction, synchronously, a kinetic approach was carried out using the 1/TBAB system and only TBAB to evaluate the activation energy (Ea ) for catalyzed and uncatalyzed reactions. The results support the synergism between the catalyst and the cocatalyst decreasing the Ea in 20.48 kJ mol−1. In addition, the thermodynamics parameters (ΔG ‡ , ΔH ‡ , ΔS ‡ ) were also determined using Eyring´s equation. Moreover, a unique example of a dormant species for catalyst 3 bearing two DMAP axially coordinated to CoII was determined by X-ray diffractometry. Theoretical studies also supported the experimental data; the catalytic cycle has been revealed at the molecular level and pointed out the best epoxide activation for the ZnII complex. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide Cyclic carbonate Porphyrin Mechanism Kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Over the last decades, many efforts have been paid to carbon dioxide (CO2) capture and utilization due to the increase of anthropological emission with the rapid development of industrialization, generating an immense amount of greenhouse gases, especially CO2 [1,2]. Despite the CO2 utilization being a long-date attitude, research on this theme was actually boosted in the last few years due to debate on climate changes and environmental problems caused by the growth of the concentration of this gas in the atmosphere [2]. Carbon dioxide is highly abundant, non-toxic, and non-flammable and it is an inexhaustible C1-source [1]. In this sense, chemists around the world have been developing methodologies that are able to transform CO2 into highly valuable products. One of the most studied reactions is the CO2 coupling to epoxides (Scheme 1 ), forming five-membered cyclic organic carbonate (COC), which can be 100 % atom efficient if the catalyst is reused. The COCs have a wide range of applications, such as solvents in Li-ion batteries, monomers to produce polycarbonates, and valuable synthetic intermediates in the fine chemical and pharmaceutical industries [1–3]. In this sense, the chemical fixation of CO2 producing COCs is a potentially useful strategy to use CO2 as green feedstock [4]. However, this transformation is not a simple task, mainly due to the very negative heat of formation of CO2 (Δ f H° = -394 kJ mol−1) and, secondly due to a few reactions that occur spontaneously with carbon dioxide [4,5]. Even though, the coupling of CO2 and epoxides to form COCs is an exothermic reaction (Δ r H = -140 kJ mol−1 for ethylene carbonate) [6], the high kinetic inertness (high activations barrier) and thermodynamically stability of CO2 turn its utilization arduous and many times require systems with high temperatures and pressures, strong bases and/or organometallic/coordination compounds to achieve good conversions. Then, the development of catalysts has a key role in improving the conversion and the selectivity of the desired product, mainly under mild conditions (e.g. P [CO2] = 1 bar and T < 60°C) [3]. Recent literature shows a series of examples that presented excellent performances under mild conditions, aiming for high conversions and no side products, such as MnIII-porphyrins (Scheme 2 ) [7], BiIII-porphyrin [8], AlIII-salen [9], AlIII, and CrIII-salphen [10], MgII-porphyrazines [11], CrIII-salophen [4] a, MnII-corrole [12], and CaII-crown ether [13]. Over the efforts to obtain excellent conversions and comprehend the direct influence of the catalyst in the activation energy, Rehman et al. [14] studied two catalytic systems in a continuous flow reactor: tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) and ZnBr2/TBAB. The results using the Arrhenius equation revealed that ZnBr2 acts by reducing the activation barrier from 55 kJ mol−1 to 32 kJ mol−1. Jiang et al. using M-porphyrin/PTAT as catalysts (M = MnIII, CoIII, or ZnII), showed that the most active MnIII-porphyrin presented Ea = 29.5 kJ mol−1, however, the obtained Ea for CoIII-porphyrin (42.2 kJ mol−1) is lower than those obtained for ZnII analog (48.9 kJ mol−1), even though zinc porphyrin presented better conversion (90 % vs 84 %) [15]. The same group has also investigated the polypropylene carbonate (PPC) and propylene carbonate (PC) selectivity using CoIII-porphyrins as catalysts in binary systems [16]. When activated with DMAP, the C2v-CoIII-porphyrin presented higher selectivity for PPC (>99 %) than the C s -CoIII-porphyrin (93 %), they demonstrated, using Arrhenius plots, that the difference between the activation energies to form PPC and PC governs the selectivity, since the ΔEa = 39.9 kJ mol−1 (ΔEa = Ea PC – Ea PPC) in C 2v porphyrin. However, in the low symmetric complex, C s , the ΔEa = 23.6 kJ mol−1, thus, producing a non-selective system. Besides kinetic approaches providing valuable data to understand the catalytic cycle, further mechanistic information regarding the plausible intermediates can be provided by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Ema et al. [17] published an insight about bifunctional metalloporphyrin investigating the anion influence (Cl−, Br−, and I−) on reaction conversion. In this sense, Li and Cao [18] investigated the cocatalyst, meso-substitutions, and the metal center influence on metalloporphyrins’ and corroles’ activity. They found the cooperative effect arising from Lewis acidic metal and nucleophilic source (Cl−) facilitate the initial ring opening. Meanwhile, even with electron-withdrawing (Cl) atoms in aryl meso positions in AlIII-porphyrins, their calculations showed a higher activation barrier than that observed for porphyrins without substituents in meso positions. However, the authors cited that non-covalent interactions should be determinant for the catalytic performance; the experimental data from Qin's work [19] shows that meso-chloroaryl substituted AlIII-porphyrin had twice the conversion of non-chlorinated analog. Manganese corroles were also tested by Tiffner et al. [12] and their DFT calculations corroborated the mechanism already proposed by Ema, [17] North, [20] and Lu [21]. Therefore, in this manuscript, we report a series of meso-tetrakis(2,3-dichloro-phenyl)porphyrins (Scheme 2) with ZnII, CuII, and CoII as metal centers and their application in CO2 cycloaddition reaction using a binary system under mild conditions (1 bar, 60°C). In order to verify the influence of the catalyst, a kinetic approach was performed using the Arrhenius Law to obtain the activation energy (Ea ) and the Eyring equation to evaluate the thermodynamic activation parameters (ΔH≠ , ΔS≠ , and ΔG≠ ), thereby, proving the synergism between the catalyst and cocatalyst. In addition, Density-functional Theory (DFT) calculations were also conducted to verify the relative energy in four expected intermediates, for all complexes. Moreover, a rare example of the crystalline structure of a dormant species [3/(DMAP)2] is reported. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents Analytical grade CH3OH, CH2Cl2, CHCl3, n-hexane, and N,N-dimethylformamide were obtained from Aldrich Chemical Co. Pyrrole was obtained from Fluka and vacuum distilled before use. All the other reagents were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. The CO2 gas (99.99 %) was purchased from Air Liquide and used without further purification. Tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), tetrabutylammonium iodide (TBAI), tetrabutylammonium chloride (TBAC), bis(triphenylphosphoranylidene)ammonium chloride (PPNC), 4-(dimethylamino)pyridine (DMAP), styrene oxide (SO), and the other epoxides were used without further purification. 2.2 Instrumentation UV-vis spectra were recorded in an HP 8453A diode-array spectrophotometer. 1H NMR spectra of cycloaddition reactions were obtained in Bruker Avance DRX 400 (400 MHz). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) was recorded in a Perkin-Elmer FTIR-BX spectrophotometer using KBr pellets over the range of 4000-400 cm−1. Raman spectra were obtained in Bruker SENTERRA Raman spectroscope, at 633 nm. The determination of the carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen content in porphyrins was performed by using a CHN Perkin-Elmer PE2400 Series II elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC – STARe thermobalance, in dynamic air or N2 atmosphere in the range of 25 – 750 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectra were obtained in Bruker micrOTOF-QII spectrometer, operating in positive mode. Solution NMR spectra were collected at ambient temperatures using Bruker Avance III 11.75 Tesla spectrometer at room temperature in deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal reference. 2.3 Synthesis of ZnII (1), CuII (2), and CoII (3) complexes meso-Tetrakis(2,3-dichlorophenyl)porphyrin (H2T2,3DCPP) was obtained by the methodology proposed by Lindsey and Wagner with adaptations [22] and characterized as proposed by Milani et al. [23]. The Zn(II), Cu(II), and Co(II) complexes were obtained by the methodology of chloroform/methanol [24]. The reaction started from H2T2,3DCPP (0.100 g; 0.12 mmol) and it produced [M(T2,3DCPP)], in which M = ZnII, CuII, or CoII and T2,3DCPP = meso-tetrakis(2,3-dichlorophenyl)porphyrin. [ZnII(T2,3DCPP)] (1), yield: 97 %. UV–Vis in dichloromethane, λmax, nm (log ε, L mol−1 cm−1): 420 (5.69); 549 (4.70). FTIR (cm−1), KBr pellets: (1,154) δCaryl-Cl; (1,000) δZn-Npyrrole, (913) δporphyrinic skeleton; (800) δC-Htrisubstituted-aryl. MS (MALDI-TOF), m/z ( %): 953.573 (100) [ZnII(T2,3DCPP)]+. [CuII(T2,3DCPP)] (2), yield: 89 %. UV–Vis in dichloromethane, λmax, nm (log ε, L mol−1 cm−1): 414 (5.33); 539 (4.12); 575 (3.36). FTIR (cm−1), KBr pellets: (1,154) δCaryl-Cl; (1,002) δCu-Npyrrole, (913) δporphyrinic skeleton; (800) δC-Htrisubstituted-aryl. MS (MALDI-TOF), m/z ( %): 950.583 (38) [CuII(T2,3DCPP)]+. [CoII(T2,3DCPP)] (3), yield: 67 %. UV–Vis in dichloromethane, λmax, nm: [CoII(T2,3DCPP)]: 412 (Soret); 530; 560. FTIR (cm−1), KBr pellets: (1,153) δCaryl-Cl; (1,008) δCo-Npyrrole, (912) δporphyrinic skeleton; (798) δC Htrisubstituted-aryl. MS (ESI-TOF) m/z ( %): 946.826 (100) [CoII(T2,3DCPP)]+. 2.4 Theoretical methodology The optimization of all structures considered for the cycloaddition reaction has been calculated using ORCA software, version 3.0.3 [25]. The Density Functional Theory (or simply DFT) calculations have been applied using the TPSSh functional [26] along the Ahlrichs' basis set def2‐SVP for lighter atoms and the triple zeta def2-TZVP for Zn, Cu, Co, and Br atoms [27]. All calculations have been conducted in Dell servers from NEQC - Núcleo de Estudos em Química Computacional at the Universidade Federal de Juiz de Fora. 2.5 General procedure for cycloaddition reactions In a general procedure, a 10 mL round flask with a magnetic stirrer was charged with complexes 1-3 (0.005 mmol, 0.1 mol %), cocatalyst (TBAB, 0.1 mmol, 1 mol %), and styrene oxide (5 mmol, 0.57 mL). A balloon of carbon dioxide (1 bar) was connected to the flask and the reaction was operated at the predetermined conditions. After the reaction was completed, the vessel was cooled to room temperature (25–30°C), and a sample was prepared for 1H NMR analysis. The 1H NMR profile of all obtained cyclic carbonates was compared to the spectra already reported in other manuscripts [28–31]. The conversion was calculated based on 1H NMR spectroscopy of the crude reaction mixture thus obtained in deuterated chloroform. Quantities were adjusted when changing the proportions, type of cocatalyst, and epoxide. 2.6 X-ray data collection and structure determination The crystallographic data for 3/(DMAP)2 were collected on a Bruker-AXS Kappa Duo diffractometer with an APEX II CCD detector. A well-shaped single crystal was selected for the X-ray diffraction data collection at 296 K under exposition to MoKα (λ = 0.71073) radiation. The programs SAINT and SADABS [32,33] were employed for indexing, integrating, and scaling. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 using SHELXS [34] and SHELXL-2018 [23] programs, respectively, included in the WinGX software package [35]. All atoms, except hydrogen atoms, were clearly identified and refined by least-squares full matrix F2 with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms were located in different maps and included as fixed contributions according to the riding model. A molecular graphic was produced with the ORTEP [24] program. It is valid to mention that 3/(DMAP)2 crystal is very weakly diffracting even at medium resolution shell. A serious problem of low long-range order is found in this structure which is mainly due to the presence of highly disordered solvent molecules. We tried to model them, however unsuccessful since their corresponding electronic density is very diffuse, outputting low Q-peaks. Therefore, medium and high-angle reflections are almost null, precluding refinement statistics. Moreover, accurate crystal structure elucidation was possible on the best dataset collected. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of ZnII (1), CuII (2), and CoII (3) complexes The porphyrin complexes [M(T2,3DCPP)] (M = ZnII, CuII, and CoII) were obtained by the chloroform:methanol procedure [36]. The starting free-base porphyrin H2T2,3DCPP was first synthesized by us in a previous study [7]; its characterization was done through UV–vis spectroscopy (See Fig. S1-S3, Supplementary Information, for comparison with those spectra for 1, 2, and 3), 1H NMR, elemental analysis, infrared, and mass spectra. In this study, we also prepared from the free-base porphyrin a new manganese one, which was employed as a catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition reactions [7]. This Mn-porphyrin presented high robustness in the studied systems, maintaining its efficiency after some runs, and keeping its structure and the metal center. For the presented complexes, metalloporphyrin complexes 1, 2, and 3 were not isolated by adding an acid to the reaction mixture, as was done for manganese porphyrin[7]. The presence of an acid species, such as HCl, could promote the demetallation of the obtained complexes as observed by ZnII- and CuII-porphyrins, which is commonly observed in an acidic medium [37]. The complex [ZnII(T2,3DCPP)] (1) presented the Soret band at 420 nm (Fig. S1, Supplementary Information, SI), characteristic of a regular porphyrin, in which the spectrum of this compound is determined by the π electrons of the porphyrinic macrocycle, with a minimal disturbance of the metal ion (ZnII, d10) [37]. The UV-vis spectra of [CuII(T2,3DCPP)] (2) and [CoII(T2,3DCPP)] (3) presented a hypsochromic shift of the Soret band (414 and 412 nm, respectively) when compared to the free-base porphyrin H2T2,3DCPP (Fig. S2 and S3 in SI). These complexes are classified as hypso-type irregular porphyrins, in which the blue-shift observed in the UV-vis spectra is a consequence of the interaction between the porphyrinic macrocycle LUMO orbitals and the eg orbitals in the metal ion [37]. It is also observed that the number of Q bands between 650 and 800 nm is reduced to one (1) or two (2 and 3) due to the increase of the porphyrin symmetry, compared to the free-base precursor [38]. The UV-vis spectrum of [CoII(T2,3DCPP)] exhibited a low-intensity band at 437 nm in the samples with a small amount of methanol. The bathochromic shift observed could be justified by the CoII oxidation, leading to [CoIII(T2,3DCPP)]+ formation [39]. To prove this observation, we verified the CoII oxidation as proposed by Chizhova et al. [39], a sample containing a mixture of [CoII(T2,3DCPP)] and [CoIII(T2,3DCPP)]+ (Soret band at 412 and 437, respectively) was solubilized in N,N-dimethylformamide and kept under magnetic agitation at 28 °C, followed by the HCl(conc.) addition to the flask. This procedure led to the [CoIII(T2,3DCPP)]Cl observed by the exclusive presence of the band at 437 nm (Fig. S4 in SI). Although the presence of electron-withdrawing substituents (such as the chlorine atoms at the ortho- and meta-positions at the meso-aryl groups) can stabilize the lower oxidation states, the porphyrin compounds tend to stabilize the state of CoIII for the complexes [39]. Furthermore, the presence of polar solvents could facilitate cobalt ion oxidation [39,40]. The metalloporphyrin complexes were also characterized by absorption spectroscopy in the IR region (Fig. S5 in SI). As already observed for manganese porphyrin complex [7], the main changes result from the absence of the band at 3,316 cm−1 characteristics of the porphyrin free base H2T2,3DCPP and the appearance of the band at ∼1,010 cm−1 referring to the presence of the metal ion coordinated to the porphyrin macrocycle. The IR-FT spectra of the [M(T2,3DCPP)] (M = ZnII, CuII, and CoII), Fig. S5 in SI, exhibited the absence of the N-Hpyrrole stretch band at ∼3,300 cm−1 and the presence of the band at ∼1,010 cm−1 concerning to the out-of-plane deformation of the metallic ion coordinated to the porphyrinic macrocycle [40]. For complexes 1, 2, and 3, the band at ∼1220 cm−1 was not completely suppressed, as observed for manganese porphyrin complex [7]. According to Boucher and Katz [41], the presence of this band is common for metalloporphyrin complexes with metal ions in a 2+ oxidation state. High-resolution mass spectrometry analyses were carried out, initially, using the ESI technique, operating in the positive mode. However, the mass spectra of [ZnII(T2,3DCPP)] and [CuII(T2,3DCPP)] (Fig. S6 e S7) did not indicate the presence of these species in the samples analysed, due to the absence of a positive charge in the complexes. The addition of formic acid promoted the demetallation of the complexes, indicating the presence of the peak at m/z 891.927 characteristics of the free-base porphyrin [23]. Thus, we performed the analysis employing the MALDI-MS technique [42] For the [ZnII(T2,3DCPP)] we verified a peak at m/z 953.573, indicating the presence of the positive ion (M+). The complex [CuII(T2,3DCPP)] exhibited the presence of a peak at m/z 950.583 (M+) and a peak at m/z 891.926 relative to the free-base porphyrin. Furthermore, in the [CuII(T2,3DCPP)] spectrum it was verified the presence of other peaks characteristics of the matrix employed in the analysis. The complex [CoII(T2,3DCPP)] was analyzed employing the ESI-MS technique and methanol as the solvent (Fig. S8) and its spectrum exhibited a peak at m/z 946.826 (M+), suggesting the presence of Co3+ species [39]. The isotopic patterns were simulated by the ChemCalc software [43] and are consistent with the observed experimental data. 3.2 Crystal structure of 3/(DMAP)2 The compound 3/(DMAP)2 was crystallized as large red needles by slow evaporation of a CH2Cl2/hexane solution of a mixture of 3:DMAP (1:20 ratio). Its crystal structure (Fig. 3) was solved in the monoclinic space group P21/n with one coordination compound in the asymmetric unit (Fig. 1 and Table S1 in SI). In addition, other low-density electronic sites were assigned to highly disordered solvent molecules, which could not be modeled. A summary of crystal data measurement and processing is shown in Table S1 (SI). The adduct 3/(DMAP)2 is made up of one divalent anionic porphyrin ligand, two neutral DMAP ligands, and one CoII ion. The coordination environment around CoII is octahedral, with the heterocyclic nitrogens of the two DMAP ligands in the axial positions and the four porphyrin nitrogens forming the octahedral basal plane [root mean square deviation (r.m.s.d.) for the four nitrogens and cobalt ion = 0.0379Å]. Co−NPorphyrin lengths range from 1.863(11) Å to 1.959(10) Å, while Co−NDMAP are 1.981(9) Å and 1.987(6) Å. The cis and trans N−Co−N angles range from 88.1(4)° to 92.3(5)° and from 177.2(5)° to 178.3(4)°, respectively. The porphyrin conformation can be described as ruffled, which has synchronous rotations on the two trans N–Co–N bonds towards opposite sides. As a result, two trans pyrrole rings are inclined by either 31.5(5)° or 33.8(6)°. Also, the most deviated atoms from the porphyrin mean plane calculated through the twenty carbons and four nitrogens (r.m.s.d. = 0.308Å) are the carbons binding the pyrrole rings. Two trans meso-carbons are deviated by 0.396(11) Å and 0.532(14) Å above the plane and the other two ones stay 0.436(14) Å and 0.547(12) Å below the corresponding mean plane, in an alternate fashion of displacement away from the basal plane featured by the four porphyrin nitrogens as the most coplanar atoms (ranging from 0.0126(9) to 0.0357(9) Å). Furthermore, all six six-membered rings are almost perpendicular relative to the 24-atom porphyrin mean plane. The dihedral angles between the former and the phenyl average planes are ranging from 78.9(4)° to 83.5(2)°, while these values are 84.9(3)° and 88.2(3)° between the macrocyclic mean plane and those calculated for the six ring atoms of the two DMAP ligands. By the way, DMAP rings are also bent by ca. 90° (85.3(2)°). Just one dichlorophenyl ring is twisted on the opposite side of the others, with its two chlorine atoms pointing out below the porphyrin average plane while those halogens of the other three substituents are directed above it. Intermolecularly, the shortest Co…Co separation is 12.159(2)Å for translation-symmetry related 3/(DMAP)2 molecules packed along the a-axis. In general, cobalt porphyrins are relatively flat, with insignificant distortions relative to the presence of axial ligands in the absence of bulky substituents in the ligands or the porphyrinic macrocycle [37]. In the structure reported in this work, the distortions observed in the porphyrinic plane could be attributed to the presence of chlorine atoms at the ortho-positions of the meso-aryl groups. Similar distortions were observed for the [MnIII(T2,3DCPP)Cl], although this compound was assigned to the C2v group [23]. The presence of two pyridine-derivates as axial ligands is common for Co(II)-porphyrins [37,44,45]. 3.3 Catalytic Studies Initially, complexes 1-3 were tested as catalysts for the coupling of CO2 and styrene oxide (SO) without solvent, under 1 bar of CO2, in 1 and 8 h, at 60°C using 0.1 mol % of catalyst (1-3) and 2 mol % of tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB). The results summarized in Table 1 showed the metal has a key role in conversion, and the most Lewis acid ZnII presented the best conversion in 1 hour (30 %) and 8 h, achieving 93 % of styrene cyclic carbonate (SCC). Replacing zinc(II) with copper(II) (2), the system achieved almost the same conversion obtained in control experiments (compare entries 3, 4 and 7, 8). This behavior was attenuated when CoII-porphyrin (3) was used as a catalyst, even though the low conversion was also obtained, even in 8 h of reaction (27 %). As shown, the epoxide activation is more difficult when 2 or 3 were employed as the catalysts, probably due to the weak interaction between the metal center and the substrate or the strong coordination of X− from TBAX which could hamper the epoxide coordination. For catalyst 2, the low conversion values obtained could be attributed to the low affinity for axial ligands in CuII-porphyrins [37], (See Table 5, theoretical investigation) hampering the epoxide activation. For these complexes (CuII, d9) the bonding in the porphyrinic plane (CuII-N) is stronger, due to the existence of a vacancy in the 3dx2˗y2orbital [46]. Also, the hybridization of 4s and 3dz2 [2] orbitals in these complexes contributes to the rise in the electron density along with the z-axis [47], (as mentioned for the CoII-porphyrins) promoting a weak axial interaction[48]. These effects were not observed for the zinc complex 1; maybe the ionic radii of zinc and the d10 nature make this metallic ion more reactive than copper and cobalt. Zinc porphyrins can coordinate several axial ligand types (such as nitrogenated bases, oxygenated derivates, and halides) [37]. Among these ligands, the equilibrium constants (Kf) for the halogenated ones are very low when compared to the interaction between the ZnIIP and nitrogenated bases [49]. In this way, we could suggest that bromide anion from TBAB acts almost exclusively in the ring-opening reaction, with minimal interaction with the zinc center, justifying the high conversion values observed. Despite the lower conversion obtained using catalysts 2 and 3, the zinc complex 1 showed excellent performance, achieving even higher TOF values (303 h−1) when compared with MnIII-porphyrin (201 h−1). This manganese catalyst presents strong electron-withdrawing groups in β-positions [7,50]. In addition, when compared to CoIIITPP/Ph3PHexBr binary system [51], in 24 h, they obtained 73 % of SCC and TOF = 20.1 h−1, at 70°C, which shows the superior efficiency of zinc catalyst 1. Also, compared to a bifunctional zinc(II) complex catalyst [Zn(Me6Tren)I]I, our system showed a higher TOF value for the conversion of styrene oxide (13.6 h−1 compared to 116 h−1), on the other hand, K. Naveen et al. used a very simple catalyst and employed it in a broad scope of epoxides [52]. Since the best activity was found using catalyst 1, it was chosen to carry out the optimization process. Then, the first parameter evaluated was the cocatalyst type, which has a strong influence on system conversion, the results are shown in Table 2 . In binary systems, the catalyst activates the epoxide and the cocatalyst provides the nucleophile to open the epoxide and act as a leaving group in the last step of the reaction. When using tetrabutylammonium halides as cocatalysts, TBAB showed to be the most effective cocatalyst, converting 93 % of SO, which can be assigned to the balance between the nucleophilicity and leaving group abilities of bromide anions [53,54]. When replacing bromide with iodide or chloride, the conversion was dramatically decreased to 48 and 47 %, respectively. Even though the conversions are similar between 1/TBAX (when X = Cl or I), the anion's nature is very distinct. The hardness/softness and nucleophilicity/leaving group abilities suggest that these two anions produce a less active system acting in different steps on the catalytic cycle. The chloride ions are well established as a poor leaving group, increasing the activation energy for the last step in the catalytic cycle, i. e. the ring closure. In contrast, iodide is a good leaving group, then, its low nucleophilicity impacts the ring-opening step and makes the reactional rate slower. The cation nature did not produce any considerable perturbation in the catalytic outcome [7,16], changing TBAC by PPNC, the conversion was increased by only 7 % with a slight decrease in selectivity from 97 to 95 %. The use of compounds containing chloride ions as cocatalysts is responsible for decreasing the selectivities when using MnIII-porphyrin [7,55], probably due to the high hygroscopicity of these compounds. Nucleophilic nitrogenated bases 4-(dimethylamino)pyridine (DMAP) and 1-methylimidazole (Me-Im) were also tested as cocatalysts, however, no SCC was detected in both reactions (entries 5 and 6 in Table 2). In contrast, Jiang et al. [56] have investigated binary (CoII-porphyrin/DMAP) and bifunctional (imidazole-functionalized CoII-porphyrin) systems and, the authors have reported high conversion using the nitrogenated portion as a nucleophile to attack the epoxide carbon [14]. Our results, using either DMAP or Me-Im, suggest the electron-withdrawing capacity of the porphyrin skeleton makes the Zn(II) ion a good electron-acceptor, which favors the coordination of axial ligands such as Me-Im and DMAP (Scheme 3 ) [7,57]. To prove such behavior, the crystalline structure of 3 axially coordinated with DMAP was obtained by mixing complex 3 in a dichloromethane solution with 20 equivalents of DMAP (Fig. 1). The equilibrium is strongly dependent on the cat:cocat ratio and, in high TBAB concentration it is dislocated to penta- and/or hexacoordinate species (A and B, respectively) [2,58]. Next, temperature dependence was evaluated, and it was shown to be crucial to achieve high conversions (Fig. 2 ). Milani et al. studied manganese porphyrins as catalysts for coupling styrene oxide with CO2 varying the temperature from 30 to 120 °C and it was observed that the epoxide conversion, TON, and TOF varied significantly with the temperature; its maximum values (TOF = 157 h−1) were achieved at 60 °C, considered the optimal temperature when using 1 mol % of TBAB [7]. Also, diol was produced as a co-product at 100 and 120 °C, decreasing the selectivity to carbonate, besides the TOF values decreased to 100 and 103 h−1 [7]. Cabral et al. [50] also studied manganese porphyrins under mild conditions; It was observed a TOF of 88 h−1 under 60 °C and 1 mol % of TBAB. In the present study, using 2 mol % of TBAB, even in ambient conditions (1 bar and 30°C), we had considerable conversion (46 %; Fig. 2), and its TOF (58 h−1) is greater than recent rare-earth phenolate catalysts (13.5 h−1) [59] or AlIII-heteroscorpionates (0.29-0.83 h−1) [60]. By increasing the temperature, we have achieved quantitative conversions at 70°C in 8 h using 0.1 mol % of 1 (Fig. 2) (TOF = 125 h−1). Even though the TOF was not as good as the heterogeneous CoII-porphyrin-based porous polymer previously reported (212 h−1) [61]. To expand our reactional scope, different epoxides were tested, and the results are presented in Table 3 . The results showed high conversions for all cases, except for cyclohexene oxide, due to the expected steric effect in disubstituted epoxides. Alkyl propylene oxide and butylene oxide were tested under ambient temperature (27°C) due to their low boiling point; in 8 h of reaction the conversions were 50 % and 45 %, respectively; when a longer time of 24 h was employed, conversions of 95 % and 82 % were achieved. In addition, all the reactions were highly selective to the respective cyclic carbonate, showing the efficiency and robustness of the system. 3.4 Kinetic studies In order to understand the effect of 1 in the conversion reaction, the reactions were conducted using SO as standard epoxide, and TBAB as cocatalyst in 1 bar of CO2 for 8 h in the temperature range between 30 and 70°C (for TBAB the range was 40 to 70°C) (see Fig.s S9-S17 and Table S2 and Table S3 in SI). The reaction conversion and selectivity were monitored by 1H NMR. The general rate equation for the cycloaddition reaction can be written as Eq. 1. The catalyst and cocatalyst concentrations and CO2 pressure do not change during the experiments, they can be considered constants and Eq. 1 may be simplified as Eq. 2 where kobs is the observed rate constant. Then, assuming pseudo-first order on epoxide concentration (a = 1) and combining Eqs. 2 and 4, the rate equation can be written as Eq. 5. By integrating Eq. 5 with respect to time, it gives the Eq. 6 which was used to obtain kobs in different temperatures [62]. (1) rate = k [ S O ] a [ C O 2 ] b [ 1 ] c [ T B A B ] d (2) rate = k o b s [ S O ] a (3) where k o b s = k [ C O 2 ] b [ 1 ] c [ T B A B ] d (4) rate = − d [ S O ] / d t (5) − d [ S O ] / d t = k o b s [ S O ] (6) − l n [ S O ] = k o b s . t The plots of SO amount with time at various temperatures using only TBAB and 1/TBAB systems are depicted in Fig. 3 , showing the strong influence of the catalyst and temperature on conversion. In Fig. 4 , two graphs were plotted showing the linear fit of all data at various temperatures for first-order kinetics plots (ln SO versus time). As expected, the increase in the temperature increases the rate of reaction, besides they showed a good fit to first-order kinetics either in the control experiment (TBAB, Fig. 4a) or 1/TBAB system (Fig. 4b). From the strong catalyst effect noted in Table 1 for zinc complex (1), we decided to evaluate the differences in activation energy between the reactions using metalloporphyrin as a catalyst and the control reaction, when only TBAB was used to produce SCC. The Ea of SCC synthesis was determined using the Arrhenius equations Eqs. 7 and (8) increasing the reaction temperature from 30°C to 70°C for the 1/TBAB binary system and from 40°C to 70°C for the TBAB system (control reaction). (7) k o b s = A . exp ( − E a R T ) (8) ln k o b s = ln A − E a R T (9) k = k b T h e x p ( − Δ G # R T ) = k b T h e x p ( − Δ H # R T + Δ S # R ) (10) ln k T = − Δ H # RT + Δ S # R + ln ( k b h ) where kb is Boltzmann´s constant and h is Planck´s constant. Initially, Eq. 8 was obtained by applying a natural logarithm on both sides in Eq. 7, which became possible with the application of the Arrhenius rule. Then, the Ea can be obtained using the natural logarithm of kobs found in Fig. 4 versus the reciprocal of the absolute temperature. The Arrhenius plot is shown in Fig. 5 a, which clearly expresses the influence of 1 in the activation barrier. The calculated Ea for both experiments is shown in Table 4 and complex 1 was responsible to decrease the Ea in 23.1 kJ mol−1, proving the catalyst had a strong positive effect on SCC production and the synergism between the catalyst and cocatalyst. The activation barrier calculated in the 1/TBAB system was lower than C2 v-M-porphyrin (where M = CoIII, Ea = 42.2 kJ mol−1 or M = ZnII, Ea = 48.9 kJ mol−1) using phenyl glycidyl ether as epoxide, however when M = MnIII (Ea = 29.5 kJ mol−1) our system presented higher activation barrier [15]. Furthermore, using the Eyring equation that correlates the rate constant, found in Eq. 4, with activation enthalpy and entropy, we can find the thermodynamic activation parameters rearranging Eq. 9 after taking the natural logarithm of both sides, given Eq. 10. Thus, the enthalpy of activation (ΔH҂) was obtained from the slope of the best-fit line from the data plotted in Fig. 5b. The entropy of activation (ΔS҂) was obtained from the interception of the best fit in the y-axis [14,63]. The data are summarized in Table 4 and, evaluating the activation enthalpy (ΔH ‡ ) of the system without zinc catalyst, it needed more energy to break the bonds in the transition state. However, when 1 is added to the system, a remarkable decrease of ΔH ‡ was noted (38.1 kJ mol−1) and the systems presented a ΔΔH ‡ = 23 kJ mol−1. Next, the activation entropy (ΔS ‡ ) showed large negative values for both systems, the more negative ΔS ‡ obtained using the 1/TBAB system indicates a higher ordered activate complex, probably due to the coordination of epoxide molecule in the metal center. The reaction also became less endergonic (ΔΔG ‡ = 5.8 kJ mol−1) when 1 is used. 3.5 Theoretical studies In order to understand the intermediates involved in the reaction mechanism DFT studies have been conducted. Firstly, four species have been considered: the first one is called Intermediate 1 (I1), where the epoxide is already coordinated to the metalloporphyrin. The second species is the one that presents the bromide linked to less hindered carbon, forming the alkoxide-metal bond (epoxide ring-opening (I2)). The third specie, the Intermediate 3 (I3) is when the CO2 is inserted, forming a carbonate-metal bond and, finally, the structure suffers a rotation to make the fourth intermediate achievable (I4), the ring-closure and the COC is already formed. The catalytic cycle is finally closed from I4 to I1 with the release of COC and the insertion of another SO molecule. Such cycle and all intermediate structures are presented in Fig. 6 for complex 1 [ZnII(T2,3DCPP)], where it is possible to follow the steps along the DFT optimized structures. Although one may have a general idea of the catalytic cycle scheme, Fig. 6 shows specific Δ r G values, in kcal mol−1, using 1 as the catalyst. Such values for the other two complexes can be found in the Supporting Information (see Tables S4 and S5 in SI). Firstly, it is possible to see that 1 has lower energy differences among the intermediates when compared to the other metalloporphyrins. This might be one more result to suggest the ZnII porphyrin presents higher conversion (also refer to Fig. S18). It is also possible to see from results in Tables S4 and S5 that the intermediate I4 seems not to be generated for CuII intermediate structures, suggesting as soon the COC is formed it is already uncoordinated from the copper center. One important feature throughout the reaction mechanism considering species I1 to I4 is to analyze the main structural differences that happen in each one. Fig. 7 shows the parameter called square dummy center (DCsq) created here to measure the distance between a center (pink ball) located inside of a grey plane formed by the four nitrogen atoms coordinated to the metal center. This distance has revealed itself quite important to display how the porphyrin is being affected by axial coordination. This parameter shows itself correlating with other structural ones such as the Metal−O bond as seen in Table 5 . The main bond lengths are presented for the sake of comparison throughout the reaction mechanism. One can be seen a regular tendency from Intermediates I1 to I4; I1-Cu is the most distorted structure and presents the largest M-O bonds, suggesting a weak interaction between epoxide and other intermediates. Fig. 7 displays I1 and I2 coordination sphere (including the dummy center) for the three metal complexes. The strongest bond was the one with a zinc ion in every intermediate, except in I1, in which both complexes (1 and 3) presented almost the same bond length (Table 5). Such behavior supports that the strongest the oxygen-metal bond the more active will be the system. Figures S19 to S22 show three views for each intermediate of all complexes, detaching some bond lengths as displayed in Table 5. Also, the metal distortion in the NNNN plane is increased when a negative formal charge in oxygen is formed (compare I1 and I2 in Fig. 7), it bringing out the metal ion and strengthening the M-O bond. Such behaviour is more evidenced in Zn and Cu porphyrins. In addition, unusual behavior is also shown in Fig. 7, the Cu porphyrin presents higher distortion related to the dummy center than Co porphyrin, however, the M-O lengths suggest stronger bonds in cobalt porphyrin (Fig. S23). 4 Conclusions In summary, three new metalloporphyrins, ZnII, CoII, and CuII (1-3), were synthesized and characterized. These complexes were tested in the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 with styrene oxide, using TBAB as a cocatalyst, under mild conditions. Cobalt and copper catalysts have not presented considerable conversions; CuII-porphyrin (2) showed to be less effective than the control experiments, suggesting a remarkable poisoning effect by the cocatalyst. However, the zinc(II) metalloporphyrin, 1, proved to be one of the most active catalysts in binary systems, achieving TOF of 303 and 125 h−1 under mild conditions (1 bar of CO2, 70°C) at 1 and 8 h, respectively. As well-known, the temperature had a direct impact on the conversion; only 43 % of SCC was formed in ambient conditions, while in 70°C, quantitative production of SCC was achieved. Moreover, the system showed strong cocatalyst´s nature dependence; whilst TBAC and TBAI presented similar conversion, for distinct reasons, TBAB showed to be the most effective cocatalyst. When nitrogenated bases such as DMAP and Me-Im were tested, the system gave no conversion, which suggests the axial coordination and poisoning of the catalytic center, as proved by a crystalline structure where CoII center in complex 3 is axially bonded to two DMAP molecules. The kinetic approach supports the strong positive effect when 1 is used as the catalyst. DFT calculations have provided the interpretation of the mechanistic insight for the whole process considering all intermediate species involved in the cycle from a molecular point of view. In summary, our results demonstrate the synergism between metal complexes and quaternary ammonium halides to produce efficient catalytic systems for the conversion of epoxides and CO2 to cyclic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: A series of new porphyrins with ZnII, CoII, and CuII (1-3) as metal centers are reported. These complexes were evaluated in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with epoxides under mild conditions (30-80°C and 1 bar of CO2 pressure) and solvent-free conditions; in optimal conditions, they presented high conversions (>99 %) and selectively produced styrene cyclic carbonate. To comprehend the mechanism of the reaction, synchronously, a kinetic approach was carried out using the 1/TBAB system and only TBAB to evaluate the activation energy (Ea ) for catalyzed and uncatalyzed reactions. The results support the synergism between the catalyst and the cocatalyst decreasing the Ea in 20.48 kJ mol−1. In addition, the thermodynamics parameters (ΔG ‡ , ΔH ‡ , ΔS ‡ ) were also determined using Eyring´s equation. Moreover, a unique example of a dormant species for catalyst 3 bearing two DMAP axially coordinated to CoII was determined by X-ray diffractometry. Theoretical studies also supported the experimental data; the catalytic cycle has been revealed at the molecular level and pointed out the best epoxide activation for the ZnII complex.
coredata.dc:title: MII-meso-tetrakis(2,3-dichlorophenyl)porphyrins as catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reaction under mild conditions: kinetic and theoretical investigation
